item.title: Debt-to-Income Ratio in Florida: What Loan Officers Actually Calculate
item.description:
Your debt-to-income ratio (DTI) is the gatekeeper for how much home you can buy. Florida loan officers use it to decide whether your payment fits. The good news: you can often improve DTI in weeks with the right moves.

What DTI measures (and the simple math)

DTI is the share of your gross monthly income that goes to monthly debts.

Formula: (Total monthly debts ÷ Gross monthly income) × 100

item.title: 2025 Conforming Loan Limits: What Middle Credit Score Borrowers Need to Know
item.description:
The Federal Housing Finance Agency (FHFA) has announced the 2025 conforming loan limits, bringing exciting opportunities for middle credit score borrowers seeking safe, government-backed financing through Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac programs.

What Are Conforming Loan Limits?

Conforming loan limits represent the maximum amount you can borrow through Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac programs while maintaining government-sponsored enterprise (GSE) backing. These limits ensure loans remain within the “conforming” category, offering borrowers enhanced security and standardized terms.

item.title: Conforming vs. Jumbo Loans in 2025: Loan Limits, Rates, and Qualification Strategies
item.description:
The difference between conforming loans and jumbo loans comes down to loan limits—conforming loans stay within FHFA maximums ($766,550 baseline for 2025, up to $1,149,825 in high-cost areas), while jumbo loans exceed these limits. This distinction affects everything: interest rates, qualification requirements, down payment expectations, and long-term costs.

For buyers in expensive markets or purchasing high-value properties, understanding the conforming vs jumbo boundary is essential for securing the best possible financing terms.

item.title: Conforming vs. Non-Conforming: How 2025 Loan Limits Shape Your Conventional Mortgage Options
item.description:
The distinction between conforming and non-conforming loans is fundamental to understanding conventional mortgage financing. Conforming loans meet Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac standards—including staying within FHFA loan limits ($766,550 baseline for 2025, up to $1,149,825 in high-cost areas)—which allows them to be sold to these government-sponsored enterprises. Non-conforming loans either exceed these limits or fail to meet underwriting standards, requiring portfolio lending with stricter requirements and typically higher rates.

Understanding whether your loan is conforming or non-conforming affects everything: interest rates, down payment expectations, qualification requirements, and long-term affordability.

item.title: Conventional Loan Limits 2025: How New Conforming Caps Shape Affordability and Opportunity
item.description: The 2025 conventional loan limits—set annually by the Federal Housing Finance Agency (FHFA)—determine the maximum loan amounts that Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac will purchase from lenders. For 2025, the baseline conforming limit is $766,550 for single-family homes in most counties, with high-cost areas reaching up to $1,149,825. These limits directly impact how much you can borrow at conforming rates, what homes you can afford, and whether you’ll need jumbo financing to complete your purchase.

item.title: Conventional Loan Limits 2025: What You Need to Know Before You Shop
item.description:
Every year, the Federal Housing Finance Agency (FHFA) announces new conforming loan limits for conventional mortgages. These limits determine the maximum amount you can borrow with a standard conventional loan before you cross into jumbo loan territory.

For 2025, the baseline conforming loan limit is $806,500 for single-family homes in most of the U.S.—up from $766,550 in 2024. But if you’re buying in a high-cost area, your limit could be significantly higher.
